choices: Find out what the visit is about
1.content:
"Mr. President," said the glowing scientist as he pointed to a small enclosure, just big enough to accomodate one person, "that is our latest invention."
"What does it do?" asked the President, as he glanced at it, already awed by the various inventions he had seen in progress in the laboratory. This one looked like his bath corner in his cabin up in the mountains, but with a tighter door and smaller perimeter.
"It is a time machine Mr. President," replied the scientist, who smiled at the hushed sounds of wonder from the rest of the President's entourage.

"It can take you anywhere in the future. I am still working on the prototype to see if we can travel back in time.""A time machine?" repeated the President. "To the future? I think this will do quite nicely."

"How does it work?" asked one of the President's guards. He had a calculated look in his eyes. The scientist was very sure that the man was calculating how to steal the contraption.
"Simple," he replied smoothly, knowing the model was nailed to the floor of the lab - there was no way it could be lifted, he smiled. "You type the year you want to visit here - its limited to four digits only. Then you enter the cubicle."

When he didnt continue for several seconds someone asked, "Then what?""Then you wait." this caused a chuckle to rise among the spectators, who thought it was all a joke. A time machine that made you wait.

Later that evening, the scientist got a surprise visit."How may I be of assistance Sir?" he asked the gentleman. The question on whether it was possible for the President of the United States of America to go somewhere without his endless trail of Secret Service Men was answered - the gentleman was alone.

"Yes," replied the gentleman, smiling slightly. "About that Time Machine, how far can it go?"

"As far as 9999,Sir" replied the Scientist. suddenly it dawned on him. The President's acute curiosity had been picked by the contraption, and he wanted to try it out.

But it was more than that. The man was a revolutionary man, who had promised the citizens a lot of progress and continued unity. He wanted to see what the future would be like. But what if something happened to him and he didnt return?
1.title: It began with Time

choices: Find out if Abraham is given the chance
11.content:
"Sir," the President began after a long pause, perhaps to gather his thoughts. "With all due respect, I would like to ask a few questions about your Time Machine and if possible, take a closer look at it."

Humbled by the title, the scientist stood up and waved to the president to follow his lead. He walked towards the bookshelf beside the fireplace. upon noticing this, the president stopped and looked at the scientist, who had a mischievous smile on his face.

The president breathed finally, when the scientist pulled aside a book and a doorway revealed itself in the stone wall. he obeyed the beckoning to follow, this time and tried to hide his surprise when they entered the laboratory he had been in earlier, after under five minutes.

"By all means Mr President," the scientist said, as he drew aside the tarp covering the Time Machine and pointed towards it.The President moved closer. He still could not put much stock in it than in his bath stall at home. But he used the opportunity to gather his thoughts again.

"Sir," he began, "May I have the honour of calling you by your first name?"

"Of course, Mr. President." came the reply.

"Then you must call me Abe, James" continued the President. "Has anybody ever tried your invention?"

"You do go straight to the point Abe," remarked James.

James Bogardus was well known for his other inventions - the cotton-spinning machine popularly called a ring flier, and the mechanized engraving machine which was now used to engrave dies for bank notes.

He was always working on something new, and his work was of interest to the political scene because of his second invention but he had come a long way. He made money from his cast-iron architecture in Washington so he was back where he started - inventing the impossible. A machine that passes through time.

The answer to the question was simple but it brought back to his mind the tireless journey he had had to go through to get there.

"Yes." he replied.

"Did the person return? How long was he gone?" asked Abraham Lincoln.

"I am standing before you Abe," James replied, "so that should answer the first question. As for the second, I was gone for a few minutes, but I spent hours in the year 2000."

Abe came closer, and began asking a lot of questions which James replied patiently. When Abe seemed to pause and let his mind assimilate all he had heard, James gave him a warning.

"When you get to there do not try to change anything or bring anything back with you. You must not change the course of history because that simple act can disrupt time and the consequences can be far reaching, even beyond our expectations."

"How do you know I want to time travel?" Abe asked, looking away from the machine for the first time in that hour. he smiled back at the inventor.

"Because that is the reason you did not laugh at my joke this morning during the inspection," replied James. "Because that is the reason the tour took place in the first place."

"You think so?" asked the reknown gentleman, as he rubbed his chin in thought.

"I know so," James replied. "And because you believe."

"I would like to explore what the future holds for slavery abolition," President Abraham Lincoln began as he paced back and forth. "If it is not abolished, what becomes of America? Will America still remain divided if I do not do something about it now? If I leave it to my successor? There are so many questions I need answered! I am concerned about the future of this country and will not do anything to jeopardize its progress as one!"

"So you think a trip to the future will aid you in your quest." James interrupted as he poured tea at the little tea table that Abraham had not noticed until then.

"Yes," exclaimed the president. "Whatever the future holds, I can see it and plan towards it, or..."

"against it."James finished off for him, as he handed over the cup of tea.

Abraham looked fleetingly at the fine bone china before taking a sip. James waited for him to finish his tea, trying hard to contain his own smile. There was no other decision - Abraham would get to travel to the future, if only once.

James Bogardus stretched his hand to receive the tea cup and saucer, and Abraham Lincoln gave it back automatically."Thank you," he murmured.
11.title: A crazy Idea

111.content:
"You realize the great risk I am taking," James interrupted the silence as he returned the tea cups and came to stand beside the sixteenth President of the United States of America, in front of the Time Machine.

"You risk your very life, I am sure," agreed Abraham. "The whole world will be against you. Your very existence, your family will be threatened. i cna picture it even now."

"I do not think that kind of future will be favourable for me," muttered James.

"No," agreed the sixteenth president of the United States of America. "I agree. But look at the good it will do the whole nation."

"Of what use is this change if you do not return?" asked James Bogardus.

"Who said I shall not return?" countered Abe.

"You shall have to promise me that you will return when the clock strikes midnight." said James solemnly. He knew very well how easy it was to get carried away by the sites and scenes of the future, by the various contraptions, the enormous buildings and even the people. He was willing to take the risk of allowing Abe a glimpse of the future, but only a glimpse. Nothing more.

"I promise to be back before midnight," Abraham Lincoln said solemnly.

As soon as the decision was made, James wasted no time. As he set up the panel that contained the buttons, he issued out instructions to Abraham. He started by telling him what to expect and how to behave before stopping himself short, his fingers hovering over the panel.

"Which year do you want to go? And where?" James asked.

"You have been to the year 2000," replied Abraham. "The new millenium. Let me also see what America has accomplished by then."

"Which state?" asked James as he punched a few more dials.

"Illinois," replied Abraham, "Let me see what has become of Chicago."

"Very well then." said James as he punched a few more, then stepped towards the door and threw it back. Steam rose from within the enclosure, making the President hesitate.

"Go in now!" exclaimed James above the noise of the machine.

The Sixteenth President ran into the closet - like contraption and felt the door slam shut in his very bones. He experienced momentary relief when he heard James shout above the din."Remember that you are to wait until you hear the whistle before opening the door! And return to the very spot at midnight!"

James' last word seemed to echo in his head, as Abraham Lincoln lost his breath suddenly. It was then that he wondered if this was not a foolish idea afterall.
111.title: The Dice is thrown

choices: The drunk does not help Abe
1111.content:
"Here we are at Chicago, Illinois, awaiting the results of the elections," a CNN reporter announced to the rest of the world. "Gathered at this rally - which seems to be the biggest rally ever to gather for a Democrat, are thousands of people from all walks of life, and from all races"His counterpart interrupted, "Its as if the whole of America is at this rally. And the songs have been encouraging. We caught a glance of Oprah, of Reverend Jesse Jackson, and other people earlier. People of all religions, all job descriptions are here."He was interrupted by his counterpart, "And the whole world is watching this particular elections - even Russia.

The whole world wants to know who will be the next president of the United States of America.""You should see the Kenyans""Yes, I hear that this election has brought about such peace in the whole country, and people have been praying even more than they prayed when a new President was to be elected in Kenya.""Its amazing how just one man can unite the whole world."

Abraham Lincoln stood in front of the Television and watched the repartee in confusion. He had opened the door and stepped into what looked like a tavern. There was a strange talking box with pictures right in front of him,and he had watched the pictures talk and listened for almost ten minutes before a drunk had shoved him aside.

"Gerrout o' my way!" the drunk man had shouted. "Halloween is o'er! You still got ur costume?"

Abraham looked at the man in his sloppy attire, and down at himself in his suit and clean polished shoes and smiled. He wondered who was wearing the costume. He ignored the drunk and approached the bar instead. He noted the least drunk man at the bar and sat beside him.

"A Good evening to you Sir," he began, giving the man his most friendly smile. "May I make your acquaintance? My name is Abra..."

"Of course your name is Abraham Lincoln!" the young man interrupted. "It goes with the costume!"Abraham stared at the man for a few seconds before he realized that if indeed he was in the future, then he was part of history. And if he was part of history then his name must be very ancient, and belong in history books about America.

"I agree." he said, still smiling. "But please may I ask a few questions?"

"Go on Abe," replied the surly young man. "Be my guest."

"Are we in the year 2000?" Abe began.

"Where have you been for the past 8 years?" asked the surly young man in a shout. It seemed the man must have been angered over something. Abe did not want to believe that the youth of the twenty - first century were this rude and deaf. Abe waited patiently for the man to answer his questions.

"No we are not in 2000," slurred the man. "We are in 2008. And in case you don't know it too, Americans are voting today for the next president of the United States of America."
1111.title: What year is this?

11112.content:
The man had said 2008, not 2000. Was Borgadus time machine faulty? If it was, will it at least take him back directly home and not make a mistake? All these thoughts were running through Abraham's head as he walked out of the tavern. He'd thanked the young man for the piece of information and left the place quickly, as he did not like the glances he was getting from other men in the room.

James had warned him that he would be treated as odd, and the best way to avoid a situation would be to always be on the move. He'd gotten to the streets and had been momentarily stunned at the number of people moving around. There seemed to be people everywhere he looked. No greenery, no fields of green, just hard concrete on the floor which was shaped in little bricks, and long poles that he concluded must light up the streets at night. He was glad that it seemed America had learnt to harness electrical power properly in the year 2008. Their clothes were funny though. The people wore different colours like they were little rainbows, and the styles were inproper and inadequate. One young girl passed by him wearing what he could not even term as appropriate for swimming, he had to turn the other way to hide his gasp.

As he walked along he saw that more people were headed in the direction he'd chose. Most of them were wearing emblems that showed a man. His curiousity piqued, Abe asked a young man what the man's name was, and the reply he got was curt, and the look unbelieving. "Obama."
Abe had nodded and thanked the man before moving along. He found a young girl all covered in badges and the national flag.

"Hello Lady," He said, bowing low before continuing. "I have been out of town for a while, please can you tell me what is happening here?"

The girl stared at him, as if expecting him to smile and tell her he was joking. When he didn't she smiled instead.
"I wonder where you went that you don't know what is going on in the US, but I will humour you." she began. "Today America will choose between the most controversial candidates to lead her for the next four years. The Republican candidate, Senator McCain is an old army general who has the unfortunate luck of being preceded by a president that dragged the party's name in mud all through his stay. The Democrat is a black man, who's father is Kenyan?"

"Kenyan?" repeated Abe, who was relieved to find someone that was willing to talk.

"You know, an African." continued the girl. "And his middle name is Hussein, and his name rhymes with the greatest terrorist America ever had: Osama."

"A black man is running for president?" shouted Abe. Around them people stopped and stared at him.

"I should have known you were rascist," sneered the girl. "Get away from me before I use my karate to break your legs!"

"NO!" shouted Abe, before looking around and reducing his voice. "It is just a pleasant surprise to me. I am not rascist. If anything I support the blacks more than anyone where I come from."

"And I am supposed to believe that?" she asked him, looking at him up and down in a contemptuous way.

"Its the truth young lady," he replied.

After a few seconds she seemed to relax.

"So we have come a long way in America," she continued. "From the abolition of slavery in 1865 by Abraham Lincoln, before he was assassinated."
Abe gasped at her statement, then quickly averted his eyes.
"Where did you go to that you don't know that Abraham Lincoln was assasinated?" asked the young lady. "That one was from history, more than 100 years ago."

"Please can you direct me to the local library?" Abraham asked instead, ignoring her question. How could he tell her that he travelled to that year from the past? As James had said, they would put him in a straitjacket instead of accept and marvel at the scientific breakthrough.

She gave him directions, and he thanked her for her time, before heading off in the opposite direction. Two hours later he came out of the enormous building with a tired smile on his face. He had read up all he could on Obama and McCain. He had read up all he could about his tenure as a president, He had read up all he could about slavery abolition and the acceptance of the blacks as people. He had read up all he could about James Borgadus's future. He had learnt all he needed to know. He was ready to go back home. Or so he thought.
11112.title: The drunk does not help Abe

111121.content:
"Please did you see a gentleman in outlandish clothes like mine in this place this evening?" the young man at the bar heard behind him. He turned around and

shook his head in confusion. Then he turned to the drunk beside him and asked,
"Is Halloween still on?"
The other guy shook his head.
"Please I asked you a question," James said again, this time in a pleading tone. He'd sent the Sixteenth President of the United States of America to the

wrong year, and he'd panicked and come in after him. He had not thought of how hard it would be to trace him.

"If you mean the guy in the Abraham Lincoln Halloween costume, yes I saw him," replied the young man, who was closer to being drunk than he was an hour

before when Abe had been with him. "He asked me so many funny questions. Thought the year was 2000, said he didn't know elections was going on, and all

sorts."

"Are you both due for a gig or something?" he asked James.

"Yes," James replied, not bothering to decipher what 'gig' meant. "We are. Please can you direct me to where he is right now?"

"Can't help you wi' that, am afraid." replied the young man. "He went out to see the town."

"Thank you." murmured James, now feeling panic anew. Chicago, Illinois in 2000 was extremely big, and overfilled with people of all sorts and ages. As he

moved towards the door, he dreaded the crowd he would be seeing on the other side.

"Why don't you call his cellphone?" suggested the young man. "Its easier that way. You can stay here and wait for him and tell me all about your gig."

"Thank you Sir, but I think its better to search for him." James said again. How was he supposed to know what a cellphone was? Was Abraham in prison?

After wandering around for another hour, James had too much information: The Democratic Rally was holding in Chicago, about 5 blocks from the tavern that

they had landed through - as if he knew what sort of blocks they were refering to; the Democratic Candidate was a black man who's father was an African; and

who had an Arabian middle name; the Republican candidate was very old, and his vice - presidential candidate was a woman. But he could not find Abe.

Despairing the more as time seemed to speed by on his pocket watch, James stood at the corner of a building, pausing for breath beside a young lady overladen

with badges that read "Obama for President". Where would Abraham go in this madness?
He asked himself.

"I take it Halloween is not over for you too," the lady said to him.

"Pardon me?" James asked, not quite understanding what she was saying.

"I thought you were friends with the guy in the Lincoln costume," she said. "You are dressed alike. But who are you playing as?"

"James Borgadus" James replied.

"Never heard of him," the lady replied.

James stared at her for a few minutes, before remembering to use the opportunity.

"Please I am looking for my friend, the person you just said wore the Lincoln attire," James said.

"Attire?" repeated the lady. "Wow. Such a quaint word. Your friend badgered me with so many questions, then asked for directions to the library."

"The library?" repeated James. "Where is that?"

She gave him directions, and waved him off as a mob of people approached them. James hurried in the direction she had pointed.

They had a little over an hour to return to the tavern and to their own time. He didn't know if the window opened after that.
He needed to find the president in time.
111121.title: James time - travels

choices: The Feds do not hear them out
1111211.content:
"Excuse me Sir." began the security official who blocked Abraham's way as he tried to exit the building. "Can you step aside for some questioning?"
Abraham looked hard at the man: his potbelly made him look unreliable, and the fact that he had a toothpick sticking out of his mouth didn't help Abraham's

mind at all. He was however wearing something that closely resembled a sheriff's uniform, and that meant the law, so Abraham did as he was told and stepped

aside.

"Please identify yourself," the man said.
"My name is Abraha.." Abraham was interrupted.
"Yeah, I know that is what you are dressed up as," the man said. "I am asking for your real name Mister."
Abraham stared hard at the man. Something told him that if he continued arguing this man would begin to suspect him for something.
"Did somebody say that anything was stolen from the library?" Abraham asked instead.
"No." the man replied, his brow furrowed.
"Do I look dangerous to you?" Abraham asked.
"No Sir," the man replied. He was obviously wondering where the questions were leading.
"Is it still a citizen's right in the United States of America to walk around and use the library?" Abraham asked.
"Yes sir." the man replied.
"Then may I ask why I am being detained right now?" Abraham asked.
The man stared at Abraham, and Abraham stared right back. Sixty seconds later, the man stepped aside.
"Sorry for delaying you Sir," he said. "We are just trying to make sure that the rally remains a safe event.You know, some goofheads already tried to kill

Senator Obama."
"Its alright." Abraham replied as he walked away briskly, in the direction he'd come from. He didn't breath until he was sure he was out of earshot from the

man. He had almost been arrested. He withdrew his gold watch from his waistcoat and gasped at the time. He'd spent two hours in the library. He had only an

hour to return to the tavern and to his own time.
That was his last thought as he felt a stunning blow at the back of his neck and he crumbled to the ground.

*****

"I am telling you the truth Sir!" shouted James at the man sitting in front of him. "I am not a criminal and I am not sick in the head as you suggest! My

name is James Borgadus and I am looking for Abraham Lincoln."

The man just sat there staring back at him. James had been asked to step aside for questioning on his way to the library. He had not hesitated when he was

asked to identify himself, but unfortunately for him, one of the police officers that had stopped him was a history buff who recogized the name instantly and

told him he was lying. The resulting argument had led to his arrest, and he was now being questioned in a small room in the police station.

James wished he had turned Abraham down now, because his confidence that he would be able to return the sixteenth president of the United States of America

to his own time was waning seriously.
"When you are through with your Halloween stories," the man questioning him finally said as he rose. "You'll give me the real deal. Let me leave you for a

few minutes so you can collect your thoughts."
James sighed in resignation. He glanced at the bare room and the thick glass wall opposite him and sighed again. He would never be able to reach Abraham now.

He could only pray that the man's curiosity was abated in the library, and that baring unforeseen circumstances, Abraham went straight back to that tavern,

and back home as he'd instructed. At least only one of them would be missing in their own time.

"He believes his own stories" the officer muttered to his counterpart as they stared at James Borgadus.
"Yeah," the other man replied. "Probably some psycho that escaped from somewhere nearby."
His partner nodded in agreement.
Three minutes later, another policeman came to join them at their watching post.
"Funny day this is," he began, after nodding at the two. "Got a guy at the library claiming to be Abraham Lincoln. All dressed up as him too, with the right

height and face. He started questioning me when I asked him to identif..."
"Abraham Lincoln?" he was interrupted.
"Yeah, old Abe himself" he replied as he watched the other two look at each other.
"I believe we have something going on here. Bring him in here let's see their reaction to each other." the policeman that had been questioning James said.
"I think we might have interrupted something big," his partner said. "Think we should call in the Feds?"

***************
"James!" exclaimed Abraham as he entered the room. "What in the world are you doing here?"
"Sir!" James exclaimed, his happiness shortlived as he realized that seeing Abraham in the police station meant one thing: He had also been arrested.
"You came to look for me?" Abraham surmised.
"Yes Sir," replied James, "after I realised I pressed the wrong dial last. I sent you to 2008, not 2000."
"What dial?" asked the police officer that had ushered Abraham in. He shook his head at their silence.
"You guys better stop your games and get serious. Its one thing to plan something dangerous on a normal day, but today is not a normal day. Today's the day

the most important event in the history of America will take place and we are not about to let some petty - minded criminals mess it up for us so you better

confess and make things easy for yourself or we are calling the Feds in"
James and Abraham glanced at each other and then at the police man.
Abraham found his tongue first. "What is 'the Feds'?"
The man's eyes widened. He could not believe that these two men would dare him. He turned on his heel and stormed out.
"Abraham, don't ask questions like that," James said. "It would only increase their curiosity and anger. They obviously don't believe we are who we say we

are, so let's stop trying to convince them. What we need to concentrate on is getting out of here in time to catch that time window in that tavern."
"How much time do we have left?" asked Abraham.
"They took my pocketwatch, but I think we should have about an hour more."replied James.
"For what its worth," Abraham began after a few seconds of silence. "I am grateful for the opportunity you have given me."
"Don't you see that its all useless if you don't return?" James shouted in frustration.
"What do you mean?" asked Abraham.
"If you don't return tonight, you will never abolish slavery, America will never be united, and today will never happen!"
"Its a good thing we are recording this," Jack Golleunez said to his partner as they listened from the other side of the thick glass. "I am sure the Feds

would find it interesting."
"Yep," agreed Godwin Letterman as he entered their listening posts again. "The Feds are on their way."
"But surely you would know that I could not have left it all hanging before I came to your house this evening?" Abraham said.
"What do you mean?" asked James.
"I left instructions that would put in motion the abolition should in case I disappear. I told my staff I wanted to lie low for a week, and made each one

believe I was in another's care."
"But with all due respect Sir," replied James. "You realize that if we do not make it to the time window in a hour's time, I am very certain your absence

will be longer than a week."
"Don't get upset James," said Abraham. "Let us apply our thinking faculties instead, to getting us out of this dilemma."
"Well said Sir," muttered James, who still felt a bit apprehensive to be arguing with the president.
Their silence was broken by the inburst of two people in suits.
1111211.title: At the Library

choices: The Feds help them back to the Bar
The Feds hold them for more questioning
11112111.content:
"Good evening gentlemen," the thinner man addressed them. "My name is Gerald Froster, and this is my colleague, Fred Atkinson."
Abraham and James accepted the handshakes proffered to them. When they continued to keep mute, the man added.
"We would like to meet you, and ask for the purpose of your visit to Chicago."
Abraham looked hard at the man as he placed a small tape recorder on the table and pressed a button, before speaking.
"My name is Abraham Lincoln, and I think this conversation would be easier on both of us if you sat down at the table as well."
The two men exchanged glances at the authority they could detect in his voice. They obeyed him silently.
"Good." he continued. "As I said my name is Abraham Lincoln and I was born in 1809. My friend here is James Borgadus, the inventor of the cotton ring-flyer, the mechanized engraving machine and all the cast - iron architecture in Washington. In our time I am the President of the United States of America."
"Are you saying that you have travelled from the past?" asked the second man in suit incredulously. His counterpart raised a hand to silence him.
"When and how did you arrive Sir?" Gerald asked.
"We arrived via the time machine that James here has invented, one after the other." Abraham replied. "James please tell these gentlemen a little bit on how it works."
James didn't see how that would help them out but he followed orders.
"Basically the machine uses time pockets that exist in our world, but these pockets are extremely small and live a short duration," James began. "What the machine does is locate an available pocket and use it to launch into whatever time you want to go to."
"So you used a time machine to get to 2008, right?" asked Gerald as he took notes.
"Yes. we did," replied James. "We landed in the washroom of a tavern called.."
"You mean a bar" Fred interrupted.
"That word was in the name," agreed James. "True Chicago Bar is its name."
Gerald tore off a note and handed it to Fred who left the room hurriedly.
"Ok, you have answered the how," said Gerald. "That still leaves out the when."
"We arrived this very evening." replied Abraham.
"And why?" asked Gerald.
"We never intended to come to 2008 in the first place," replied Abraham.
"No?"
"No." replied James. "I have been to Chicago, in the year 2000. I was supposed to send him to the same time and period but I made a mistake with the digits and typed 8 instead of another zero. When I noted my mistake I came in after him to get him. I was on my way to meeting him at the library when I was arrested by the sheriffs. They didnt believe me at all. They thought I was mentally ill."
"That is understandable Mr. James," stated Gerald as he refrained from correcting James that they were policemen not sherriffs. "Put yourself in their shoes.

A man in a funny suit says his name is the same as someone who died over 100 years ago, and he is looking for Abraham Lincoln, who is also dead for over a hundred years. The man will either be a ghost, or a sick man."
"So you had no idea of what's happening in the country at the moment?" Gerald continued.
"I did not." replied Abraham. "I began asking questions from inside the tavern especially after I heard a talking box with pictures. I headed for the library to see what information I could find."
"Neither did I," added James. "But from what I can gather the whole country is awaiting election results. One of the candidates is a black man, of African descent."
"That should make you happy Sir," James said directly to Abraham, who nodded with his first smile in hours.
"Yes, indeed it does," he said, before turning to Gerald. "That is the major reason I decided to travel. I wanted to see the future of the country if I insisted on the abolition of slavery. In our time, it has reached a defining point, and I am about to take my stand, but I was curious as to how it would all
end."
"And what did you find?" asked Gerald silently.
"I combed through all that has happened since our present day and I must say that I am glad at the way things turned out." replied Abraham. "Slavery has become a thing of the past, and the United States of America is still a free country. And its still one entity, and not divided."
"So how do you intend to return to your own time now that your curiosity has been satisfied?" Gerald asked as Fred rushed back in with two notes.
Gerald raised an arm to stop James from speaking as he opened the notes to read. Then he nodded at Fred before looking at James.
"The time pocket lasts up to 3 hours, 4 hours at most. We are supposed to pass though at midnight." James explained.
"So how much time do you have left?" asked Fred.
"We were stripped of our watches when we got here," replied Abraham, "but we had an hour before then."
"That's long before the announcement of the results, right?" Fred asked Gerald, who nodded in affirmation. Gerald turned to Abraham and James.
"Then it appears that we have to hurry," he said with a smile as he rose from the seat. "Give me a minute to arrange your transportation back to the bar."
When he got out of the room, he faced Godwin and Jack
"Those guys are definitely sick upstairs," he said.
"But can two people be sick together? Believe their own delusions together?" asked Godwin.
"That's what makes it so spooky," replied Jack."But their stories are straight so far, and I am talking about from the bar. Even the girl selling badges on
the sidewalk remembered them,"
"So what do we do about this?" asked Godwin.
11112111.title: The Feds hear them out

choices: They are taken to the Senator
They are detained for a longer period
111121111.content:
"That bar is about 5 blocks away from the rally site," muttered Gerald. "Either they need to get back into that bar to set off a time bomb or they want media attention and developed an outlandish story like this one to get it."
"This would definitely be newsworthy," noted Godwin. "Life as a shrink must be interesting if these are the kind of cases I get to treat everyday."
"Life as a shrink is very dangerous," corrected Jack. "My Dad was killed by a wacko because he actually believed the guy was innocent."
"The guys I sent to comb that bar for anything remotely explosive should be through any minute now." Fred said, glancing at his watch.
"What are your options?"
"Take them to the bar if its clean, and watch them 'disappear' as they claim." Gerald responded. "If its not clean, take them away for further questioning."
Fred came out of the questioning room then, as he closed his flip cell phone to end a call.
"Coast is clear at the bar." he said. "What do we do?"
"We take them straight to their time machine then." Gerald said heartily.
As the two men waited for the police to clear the time-travelers, Fred asked Gerald, "Do we need to report this to the Senator as he asked us to?"
Senator Obama had explicitly requested that all activities be reported to him regardless of how trivial it was.
"These men will be gone soon." Gerald replied. "What good will it do to expose the senator to this? We can just file this in a report. He can read it later, after celebrating the election results."
"Good point," added Fred. "Its better that way, killing two bir..." he was interrupted by his cell phone ringing. As the head of the unit in charge of ensuring the safety of the presidential candidate and his family's life, he had a good personal rapor with Senator Obama so much so that the man was always quick to notice his absence, even for thirty minutes. Without a doubt his absence had been noticed.
"Hello Gerry," Senator Obama said into the phone. "Where are you?"
"At the local police station sir," Gerald replied. The senator was among the very few people he allowed to call him 'Gerry'. The only other person was his mother.
"What's cooking over there that needed your attention?"
"Nothing serious sir," Gerald responded. "Just a couple of time-travelers that missed their way."
"Time-Travelers?" repeated the Senator. "That is interesting. Whatever will they come up with next?"
"That's what keeps this job interesting sir," Gerald said.
"Bring them here for further questioning?" asked the senator.
111121111.title: The Feds help them back to the Bar

1111211112.content:
"Not yet sir," Gerald replied. "Their claims have to be falsified first. We have about three hours before the results will be announced so its no hurry."
"Hmm...."was the senator's response, and Gerald already knew the next question. When the would-be assassins that had made an attempt on his life had been caught, the senator actually wanted to talk to the men, to ask them why. Gerald knew the request would be the same this time, never mind that he was putting himself in danger by doing such a thing.
"Gerry, where are you taking them?" asked the senator.
"To the bar they claim houses their time machine, Sir" replied Gerald."We have cleared the place so there can be no issue of other accomplices in the crowd to aid them in anyway."
"Great." said the senator. "Can I come and watch? I wont be an accomplice I promise."
Gerald had to smile. This man that the world took very seriously had his funny side as well. But could he actually put the senator's life in danger, three hours from his victory being announced? No way.
"I'm sorry sir but you will have to pass on this one," Gerald responded. "Its not uncommon to make an attempt on a candidate's life hours before the election results have been announced. We would be putting you in grave danger if we exposed you to these men who might just be leading us on a merry dance as we speak."
"You can hide me, Gerry" replied the senator.
"How?" Gerald could not help asking.
"You say these men claim to be from another time, right?"
"Yes sir," replied Gerald. "They claim to be Abraham Lincoln and James Borgadus from a century ago."
"Then they would not recognize me if they saw me, but just to be safe, I can dress up as the bar tender, and add a little makeup to make me look older or something."
Gerald breathed in sharply, counted to ten then exhaled.
"That is not a disguise at all sir," he replied. "They might be pretending until they have their target - you."
"Ok, I knew you'd say that," the Senator was actually smiling. "Can I have a camera view of everything then?"
"That is a much better option sir," Gerald said. "It can be arranged."
"Thank you Gerry," the senator said, then cut the phone call.
Gerald shook his head in amazement. The senator never did see the danger in any situation. He began to make calls to set up the video stream in the bar.
1111211112.title: They are not taken to the Senator

choices: The Senator is allowed into the bar
The Senator is not allowed into the bar
11112111121.content:
"Sir," Abe said suddenly as they entered the bar. Fred and Gerald were on the alert. "I would like to leave a little note for the next president before I leave."
James heard this and turned. "With due respect Mr President, writing a note to the next president does not tally with what I insisted upon in my lab back home. We are not to try to alter the future in anyway because we do not know how it will affect the past and our own time."
"But we have already affected the future, James," replied Abe. "The men that arrested us, and these men that have been so kind as to help us, will have it on record that we came here."
"Sir they will have it on record that some crazy people claiming to be you and me came here," James responded. "There is an acute difference Sir."
Gerald and Fred watched in silence. Fred faced Gerald and mouthed 'delay tactic', and Gerald nodded in response. Abe, being taller than all of them, saw this however, and sighed.
"They think we are stalling, James" he said. "Please lead the way."
James led them to the cloakroom through which he'd landed. Gerald and Fred watched as he opened the door slightly, then pointed for Abe to go in first.
"No James, you go in first this time," Abe said. "I will follow immediately. Besides I hope we wont be muddling things if I went in first since you came out last."
James nodded, then turned to the other two men. "Thank you for believing us. I will search for your ancestors in my time to repay the kindness."
All Fred and Gerald could do was nod in response.
James closed the door, and they waited. Nothing happened. No noise, no blinding light.
Gerald glanced at Abe, "You sure its not broken?"
"I do not know," Abe responded. "Its James' invention not mine."
After waiting for ten minutes, Gerald lost his patience and yanked open the door. It was empty.
He panicked. He grabbed his radio and began shouting orders for his men to begin searching for James within ten miles of the area. Then he called for the experts to come and study the room more closely - it was obvious that they had missed something in their early search.
Abe just stared, and watched as three men and a woman came and began running their hands all over the room. After ten minutes Abe walked up to Gerald.
"I beg your pardon but I really need to be going now. I have barely thirty minutes left before midnight."
"Is something happening at midnight?" Gerald asked.
"Yes," replied Abe. "According to James, the time pocket is likely to close then, and that means I will be stranded here indefinitely."
Before Gerald could find an apt response, a hush fell on the rest of the crowd. Gerald turned around to see why: The senator was at the door of the bar.
11112111121.title: At the Bar

111121111211.content:
He quickly looked at Abe to see his reaction. The tall man jsut raised an eyebrow in question as to what was going on. He gave Senator Obama one glance, then turned back to Gerald and pleaded that he be allowed to return to his time before they continue searching for whatever it is they were searching for.
Gerald and Fred were impressed.
Senator Obama walked up to them and nodded his head to Fred and Gerald, before facing Abe.
"A good day to you Mr President," he said, as he extended his hand. Abe turned round, looked at the man, then the extended hand, and shook it warmly.
"You are the first person in this era to address me thus," he said in response. "Perhaps you might be of help in this situation sir."
"What is the situation Mr President?"
"These men allowed my friend to return to our time, but they have refused to give me right of passage."
"And why is that?" The Senator asked Gerald.
"The other man just dissappeared into thin air, Sir," replied Gerald. "We are just checking for foulplay."
"and delaying the sixteenth president of the United States of America in the process," added the senator.
"And obviously without explanation," added the Senator's wife as she strode unto the scene. She waved at the workers with a smile before facing the men.
"Mr President we are sorry for the delay," she said, taking charge of the situation. "This generation is extremely curious and always seeks out a logical explanation for every event. I should hope that they wouldn't take much longer sir."
"Three more minutes," shouted the woman that was searching the door, "of futility." she added in a whisper.
"I heard that," Mrs Obama responded, but with a smile.
"Sir, if we could just move over there and sit and wait patiently I am sure they'll be done quickly." The Senator offered as he pointed to the seating area of the bar. Abe nodded.
Abe glanced outside as he sat, and was surprised to see so many people in the same ensemble standing outside the room.
"Is the army outside?" he asked.
"Well, its an army of sorts," the senator's wife replied. "Their duty is to protect the president-elect from any harm or attack."
"I see," Abe said, finally realizing with whom he was conversing. "Back in my time I could walk freely among my own. I didn't need an army to follow me about."
"Since then sir, there have been several assassinations, and attempts on very special people's lives," the senator said. "These were the measures prescribed for protection."
"Yes," agreed Abe. "I have read about them, even my own." he muttered to himself
"Are you not jeopardizing your safety to associate with me?" Abe asked.
"Yes we are," replied the senator. "But the minute I saw you I knew you were no fake."
"I must congratulate you for your successful climb to where you are now, young man," Abe said to him. "You have indeed worked very hard to get there, in a time when corruption seems to be the order of the day."
For once, the senator had no response for such high praise.
"I have also read about the current world situation," continued Abe. "and while I am extremely pleased to see that the whole world seems to look up to America for guidance, the situation in the Arabian world is not a source of joy for me. And what the present president has done so far does not help matters. It is your duty as a nation to ensure that others also live in peace around you, else they look upon you with scorn which in time develops into hatred that might lead to an attack."
"We will do our best sir," the senator replied modestly. Abe continued giving advice on several matters he'd read about in the two hours he'd spent in the library.
"You speak as if my husband's winning this election is a foregone conclusion, Mr President," The senator's wife commented.
"Yes it is indeed," Abe responded. "His opponent is extremely weak, does not have his facts straight and is low. I do not expect any difference in the results from what I can see. Your husband is the next president of the United States of America."
Gerald had been about to inform them that the coast was clear, when he caught that information.
Abe saw him stop midstride and asked, "Is it time?" To which the young man nodded. The three of them arose at the same time and walked back to the cloakroom door.
"It was a great honor to have met you Mr. President," The senator said as Abe turned around, presumably to say farewell.
"No," Abe responded. "The pleasure was all mine. I am glad I embarked upon this journey, because it gives me confidence to do what I have to in my own time, to ensure that today will take place. Farewell."
And with that he closed the door behind him.
111121111211.title: The Senator is allowed into the bar

1111211112111.content:
"What took you so long Mr President?" James Borgadus said as he helped the tall man out of the cubicle and into a seat. "You had me frantic with worry."
"After you were gone the men went crazy." Abe said.
"But why? How?"
"They did not believe that some trick was not involved with your departure," replied Abe. "So they proceeded to search every surface area in that cloakroom for a clue or button."
"What did you do in the meantime?" asked James. "And did they find anything?"
"The black presidential candidate came to see me," replied Abe as he accepted the cup of tea James extended to him. "No they didn't find anything - what would you have done if they did?"
"Filed the information away." replied James. "I always wondered why the time pocket chose where it did as the end point. My early theory is that it is a random selection."
"Well, I had a brief chat with the candidate and his wife." continued Abe thoughtfully. "It was enlightening and I am grateful for the opportunity, James."
"The gratitude is all mine, Sir" replied James.
"It was quite an advanture," added Abe. "At least I now know the date of my death and the manner in which it will take place."
He looked at James' aghast expression and added. "I even know who will do it. It is an invaluable piece of information, and I intend to use it appropriately."
"How sir?" James could not help asking, as he watched the president rise and walk toward the general doorway.
"Why, I will plan ahead of course. I might not have the time to visit you again for a while, James, but I will never forget your kindness and invention."
1111211112111.title: Back in Abe's Time

info.brief_description: What happens when someone from the past visits present day Earth? How different'll it be?
info.description:
What happens when someone from the past visits present day Earth? How different do you think it will be from their own time? What differences do you think they would be most unhappy about?

It is the year 1864, and a scientist creates a time machine to transport him through time, but no one believes his invention works, until a very important dignitary comes to him for help....only his idea is so crazy and out of this world that the scientist at first wonders if it is possible.....

Please read the story to the end before adding, And take note of the major characters involved - don't shift the focus from them.
